revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Military dictatorship of Chile (1973–90) to [[:Category:Military dictatorship of Chile (1973–1990)]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{More citations needed|date=May 2009}} {{Update|inaccurate=yes|date=March 2010}} }} {{History of Chile}} The '''Chilean transition to democracy''' began when a Constitution establishing a transition itinerary was approved in a plebiscite. From 11 March 1981 to March 1990, several organic constitutional laws were approved leading to the final restoration of [[democracy]]. After the 1988 plebiscite, the [[Constitution of Chile|1980 Constitution]], still in force today, was amended to ease provisions for future amendments to the constitution, create more seats in the senate, diminish the role of the National Security Council and equalize the number of civilian and military members (four members each).
[[Christian Democratic Party of Chile|Christian Democrat]] [[Patricio Aylwin]] served from 1990 to 1994 and was succeeded by another Christian Democrat, [[Eduardo Frei Ruiz-Tagle]] (son of [[Eduardo Frei Montalva]]), leading the same coalition, for a six-year term. [[Ricardo Lagos Escobar]] of the [[Chilean Socialist Party|Socialist Party]] and the [[Party for Democracy (Chile)|Party for Democracy]] led the [[Concertacion]] to a narrower victory in the 2000 presidential election. His term ended on March 11, 2006, when [[Michelle Bachelet Jeria|Michelle Bachelet]] of the Socialist Party took office.<ref name="USDoS">{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/1981.htm|title=Background note|publisher=Department of State}}</ref> Center-right investor and businessman [[Sebastián Piñera]], of the [[National Renewal (Chile)|National Renewal]], assumed the presidency on March 11, 2010, after Bachelet's term expired. Bachelet returned to the office on March 11, 2014, being succeeded by Piñera in the following term (2018-2022).
==1988 plebiscite and reform of the Constitution== {{main|Chilean national plebiscite, 1988}} Passed under tight military control in 1980, the [[Constitution of Chile|Chilean constitution]]'s legal dispositions were designed to lead to the convocation of all citizens to a [[plebiscite]] during which the Chilean people would ratify a candidate, proposed by the Chief of Staff of the [[Chilean Armed Forces]] and by the General Director of the [[Carabineros de Chile|Carabineros]], the national police force, and who would become the [[President of Chile]] for an eight-year term. In 1980, this meant that the [[Chilean people]] were supposed to approve [[Augusto Pinochet]]'s candidacy, assuring him popular legitimacy and the sanction of a [[vote]]. Should the people refuse the junta's chosen candidate, the military would relinquish political control to the civilians, convoking the following year presidential and parliamentary [[democracy|democratic elections]], and thus putting an end to the military government. In 1987, Pinochet's government passed a law allowing the creation of [[political parties]] and another law allowing the opening of national registers of voters. If the majority of the people voted "yes" to Pinochet's plebiscite, he would have remained in power for the next eight years, but Congress would have been elected and installed on March 11, 1990, as in fact happened.
{{Quote|''Touch only one of my men, and forget about the rule of law.''|Augusto Pinochet, 1989<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hnHSNena2vkC&pg=PA204&lpg=PA204&dq=si+me+tocan+el+estado+de+derecho+pinochet&source=bl&ots=6vX_SaQth2&sig=kLdMdww6UnItUQ-h-xzru-LpANs&hl=en&sa=X&ei=WCV2VZmgGM7e7Aa6n4CQAQ&ved=0CD4Q6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=si%20me%20tocan%20el%20estado%20de%20derecho%20pinochet&f=false |title=Educación para la Ciudadanía: Democracia, capitalismo y estado de derecho |publisher=[[Ediciones Akal]] |accessdate=2015-06-08 |isbn= |page=204 |language=Spanish |year=2007}}</ref>}}
===Context and causes of Pinochet's decision to follow the Constitution=== Among various causes of Pinochet's decision to resume this procedure, the situation in the [[Soviet Union]], where [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] had initiated the [[glasnost]] and the [[perestroika]] democratic reforms, which would finally lead to the fall of the [[Berlin Wall]] in 1989 and to the official end of the [[Cold War]], is clearly an important factor. The Cold War had important consequences in [[South America]], considered by the [[United States and South and Central America|United States to be a full part]] of the Western Bloc, in contrast with the [[Eastern Bloc]], a division born with the end of [[World War II]] and the [[Yalta Conference]]. Following the 1959 [[Cuban Revolution]] and the local implementation in several countries of [[Che Guevara]]'s [[foco theory]], the US waged a war in South America against the "[[Communists]] [[subversion (politics)|subversives]]," leading to [[United States intervention in Chile|support in Chile]] of the right-wing, which would culminate with the coup of 1973 in Chile. In a few years, all of South America was covered by similar military dictatorships, called ''[[military juntas|juntas]]''. In [[History of Paraguay|Paraguay]], [[Alfredo Stroessner]] was in power since 1954; in [[History of Brazil|Brazil]], left-wing President [[João Goulart]] was overthrown by a [[History of Brazil (1964–1985)|military coup in 1964]]; in [[History of Bolivia|Bolivia]], General [[Hugo Banzer]] overthrew leftist General [[Juan José Torres]] in 1971; in [[History of Uruguay|Uruguay]], considered the "Switzerland" of South America, [[Juan María Bordaberry]] seized power in the June 27, 1973 coup. A "[[Dirty War]]" was waged all over the continent, culminating with [[Operation Condor]], an agreement between security services of the [[Southern Cone]] and other South American countries to repress and assassinate political opponents. Militaries also took power in [[History of Argentina|Argentina]] in 1976, and then supported the 1980 "Cocaine Coup" of [[Luis García Meza Tejada]] in Bolivia, before training the [[Contras]] in Nicaragua where the [[Sandinista National Liberation Front]], headed by [[Daniel Ortega]], had taken power in 1979, as well as [[Guatemalan Civil War|militaries in Guatemala]] and in [[History of El Salvador|El Salvador]]. In the 1980s, however, the situation progressively evolved in the world as in South America, despite a [[Cold War (1979-1985)|renewal of the Cold War]] from 1979 to 1985, [[Cold War (1985-1991)|the year]] during which Gorbatchev replaced [[Konstantin Chernenko]] as leader of the USSR. [[File:Visita de Juan Pablo a la PUC (33437732200).jpg|thumb|It is believed that the visit of Pope John Paul II in April 1987 may have influenced Pinochet's decision to call for elections. The Pope is shown here at the [[Pontifical Catholic University of Chile]] on April 4, 1987.]] Another alleged reason of Pinochet's decision to call for elections was the April 1987 visit of [[Pope John Paul II]] to Chile, during which he visited [[Santiago de Chile|Santiago]], [[Viña del Mar]], [[Valparaíso]], [[Temuco]], [[Punta Arenas]], [[Puerto Montt]] and [[Antofagasta]]. Before the pontiff's pilgrimage to [[Latin America]], during a meeting with reporters, he criticized Pinochet's regime as "dictatorial." In the words of ''[[The New York Times]]'', he was "using unusually strong language" to criticize Pinochet and told the journalists that the Church in Chile must not only pray, but actively fight for the restoration of democracy in Chile.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/01/world/pope-on-latin-trip-attacks-pinochet-regime.html?pagewanted=1 Pope, on Latin Trip, Attacks Pinochet Regime] ''The New York Times'', April 1, 1987</ref> During his 1987 Chilean visit, the Polish pope asked Chile's 31 Catholic bishops to campaign for free elections in the country.<ref>[http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1P2-1314763.html Pope Tells Chile's Bishops To Press for Free Elections; Pontiff Joins Pinochet on Palace Balcony] [[The Washington Post]], April 3, 1987</ref> According to [[George Weigel]], he held a meeting with Pinochet during which they discussed the topic of the return to democracy. John Paul II would have allegedly pushed Pinochet to accept a democratic opening of the regime, and would even have called for his resignation.<ref>[[Heraldo Munoz]], ''The Dictator's Shadow: Life under Augusto Pinochet'', p. 183, Basic Books (2008), {{ISBN|0465002501}}</ref> In 2007, Cardinal [[Stanisław Dziwisz]], Pope John Paul II's secretary, confirmed that, during his visit with Pinochet, the Pope asked him to step down and transfer power over to civilian authorities.<ref>[[George Weigel]], ''Biografía de Juan Pablo II - Testigo de Esperanza'', Editorial Plaza & Janés (2003), {{ISBN|84-01-01304-6}}</ref> During his visit to Chile, John Paul II supported the [[Vicariate of Solidarity]], the Church-led pro-democracy, anti-Pinochet organization. John Paul II visited the Vicariate of Solidarity's offices, spoke with its workers, and "called upon them to continue their work, emphasizing that the Gospel consistently urges respect for human rights."<ref>Timmerman, Jacobo ''Chile: Death in the South'', p. 114, Alfred A. Knopf, Inc., 1987 {{ISBN|978-0-517-02902-2}}</ref> Some have erroneously accused John Paul II of affirming Pinochet's regime by appearing with the Chilean ruler in his balcony. However, Cardinal [[Roberto Tucci]], the organizer of John Paul II's pilgrimages revealed that Pinochet tricked the pontiff by telling him he would take him to his living room, while in reality he took him to his balcony. Tucci claims that the pontiff was "furious."<ref>[http://wyborcza.pl/1,75477,7396637,Dlaczego_Jan_Pawel_II_wyszedl_z_Pinochetem_na_balkon.html Dlaczego Jan Paweł II wyszedł z Pinochetem na balkon] [[Gazeta Wyborcza]], December 24, 2009</ref>
Whatever the case, political advertisement was legalized on September 5, 1987, and became a key element of the campaign for the "NO" to the referendum, which countered the official campaign which presaged a return to a Popular Unity government in case of a defeat of Pinochet. Finally, the "NO" to Pinochet won with 55.99% of the votes, against 44.01% of the votes. Thus presidential and legislative elections were called for the next year.
Furthermore, in July 1989, a [[Chilean referendum, 1989|constitutional referendum]] took place after long negotiations between the government and the opposition. If approved, 54 constitutional reforms were to be implemented, among which the reform of the way that the Constitution itself could be reformed, the restriction of [[state of emergency]] dispositions, the affirmation of [[pluralism (political philosophy)|political pluralism]], the strengthening of constitutional rights as well as of the [[democracy|democratic]] principle and participation to the political life. All parties in the political spectrum supported the reforms, with the exception of the small right-wing Avanzada Nacional and other minor parties, and the reforms were passed with 91.25% of the vote
==Aylwin administration== Representing the ''[[Concertación]]'' coalition which supported the return to democracy, gathering the [[Christian Democrat Party of Chile|Christian Democrat Party]] (PDC), the [[Socialist Party (Chile)|Socialist Party]] (PS), the [[Party for Democracy (Chile)|Party for Democracy]] (PPD) and the [[Social Democrat Radical Party]] (PRSD), Christian Democrat [[Patricio Aylwin]] won a sweeping victory in the [[Chilean presidential election, 1989|first democratic elections]], in December 1989, since the [[Chilean presidential election, 1970|1970 election]] won by [[Salvador Allende]]. Patricio Aylwin had gathered around him 3,850,023 votes (55.17%), while the center-right supermarket tycoon [[Francisco Javier Errázuriz Talavera]], who represented the [[Progressive Union of the Centrist Center|UCCP]] party, managed to take 15.05% of the vote, which had as main effects to lower right-wing candidate [[Hernán Büchi]]'s score to 29.40% (approximately 2 millions votes, almost half than Patricio Aylwin). [[File:Aylwin Banda (2).jpg|thumb|In December 1989, Patricio Aylwin, head of the ''Concertación'' coalition, won the first democratic election in Chile since 1970.]] The ''Concertación'' coalition dominated Chilean politics for much of the next two decades. It established in February 1991 the [[National Commission for Truth and Reconciliation]], which released in February 1991 the [[Rettig Report]] on human rights violations during Augusto Pinochet's dictatorship. This report, contested by human rights NGOs and associations of political prisoners, counted 2,279 cases of "[[forced disappearance|disappearances]]" which could be proved and registered. Of course, the very nature of "disappearances" made such investigations very difficult, while many victims were still intimidated by the authorities, and did not dare go to the local police center to register themselves on lists, since the police officers were the same as during the dictatorship.
The same problem arose, several years later, for the [[Valech Report]], released in 2004 and which counted almost 30,000 victims of [[torture]], among testimonies from 35,000 persons. However, the Rettig Report did list important detention and torture centers, such as the [[Esmeralda (BE-43)|Esmeralda ship]], the [[Estadio Nacional de Chile|Víctor Jara Stadium]], [[Villa Grimaldi]], etc. The registering of victims of the dictatorship, and then, in the 2000s, trials of military personnel guilty of human rights violations, would dominate the struggle for the recognition of crimes committed during the dictatorship by human rights NGOs and associations of political prisoners, whom many resided in exile.
Beside implementing the Rettig Commission, Aylwin's government established a ''Comisión Especial de Pueblos indígenas'' (Special Commission of Indigenous People), whose report provided the intellectual framework of the "Indigenous Law" (''ley indígena'') or law n° 19 253, promulgated on September 28, 1993,<ref>[http://www.uta.cl/masma/patri_edu/PDF/LeyIndigena.PDF LEY Nº 19.253 - LEY INDÍGENA] {{es icon}}</ref> which recognized in particular the [[Mapuche]] people as inherent part of the Chilean nation. Other indigenous people officially recognized included [[Aymara people|Aymara]]s, [[Atacameña]]s, [[Kolla people|Colla]]s, [[Quechua people|Quechua]]s, [[Rapa-Nui]], [[Yámana]]s and [[Kawashkar]]s. Despite this state proclamation of indigenous rights, conflicts brought by land-occupations and Mapuche's claims led to state repression and the use of the anti-terrorist law against Mapuche activists, a law voted by the military ''junta''.
==Frei Ruiz-Tagle administration== {{main|Chilean presidential election, 1993}} Preparing for the [[Chilean presidential election, 1993|1993 election]], the Concertación held primaries in May 1993, opposing on its left-wing [[Ricardo Lagos]] ([[Party for Democracy (Chile)|PPD]]) to Christian-Democrat [[Eduardo Frei Ruiz-Tagle]], ([[Christian Democrat Party of Chile|PDC]]), the son of former President [[Eduardo Frei Montalva]] (1911–1982, President from 1964 to 1970). Eduardo Frei won these primaries by a large majority of 63%.
The right-wing, grouped in the [[Alliance for Chile]], also held primaries opposing [[Sebastián Piñera Echenique|Sebastián Piñera]] ([[National Renewal (Chile)|National Renewal]], RN, the largest right-wing party at the time), who had supported the "NO" during the 1988 plebiscite on the return to civilian rule, to [[Arturo Alessandri Besa]], former member of the [[National Party (Chile)|National Party]] (PN, opposed to Eduardo Frei in the [[Chilean presidential election, 1970|1970 presidential election]]) and currently representant of the [[Independent Democrat Union]] (UDI). Alessandri won those, and thus represented the Alliance for Chile against the Concertación.
Others candidates included [[José Piñera]], former Minister in the early 1980s who had implemented the law granting property of [[copper]] to the [[Chilean Armed Forces]], who presented himself as an independent (6%); ecologist [[Manfred Max-Neef]] (5.55%), representative of the ''Left-Wing Democratic Alternative'' (which gathered the [[Communist Party of Chile|Communist Party]] (PCC), [[MAPU]] (part of the [[Popular Unity (Chile)|Popular Unity]] coalition of Allende) and the [[Christian Left Party (Chile)|Christian Left Party]]); [[Eugenio Pizarro Poblete]] (less than 5%); and finally [[Cristián Reitze Campos]] of the left-wing [[Humanist Party (Chile)|Humanist Party]] (1.1%).
On 28 May 1993, the ''Boinazo'' took place, during which paratroopers surrounded the Chilean Army headquarters located close-by to the [[Palacio de la Moneda]].<ref>[http://www.tcgnews.com/santiagotimes/index.php?nav=story&story_id=14609&topic_id=15 Chile: Illicit Croatia Arms Sale Case in Final Stage], ''[[The Santiago Times]]'', 4 September 2007 {{en icon}}</ref> The motive of the military uprising was the opening of [[Augusto Pinochet's arrest and trial|investigations concerning the "Pinocheques"]], or checks received by Pinochet for a total amount of $3 million in the frame of kickbacks from an arms deal.<ref name=Boinazo>[http://www.sii.cl/SIIPRENSA/2005/2509/02.htm El verdadero objetivo del "boinazo" de Pinochet] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070911134856/http://www.sii.cl/SIIPRENSA/2005/2509/02.htm |date=2007-09-11 }}, ''Diario Siete'', 25 September 2005 {{es icon}}</ref> But, unnoticed at the time, a few days before, Jorge Schaulsohn, President of the Chamber of Deputies, had also denounced irregularities during arms trade committed by the [[Chilean Army]] through the intermediary of the FAMAE (Factories and Arsenals of the Army of Chile) — much later connected to the [[Gerardo Huber]] case, who was assassinated the year before.<ref name=Boinazo/>
Frei Ruiz-Tagle finally won the election in the first turn, held in December 1993, with an [[absolute majority]] of almost 58%, and more than 4 millions votes against Arturo Allesandri who gathered around 1,700 000 votes (24.4%). Eduardo Frei took office in March 1994 and presided for a 6-year term, until 2000. During his term, it was not possible to judge any military for his role during the dictatorship, while large sectors of the Chilean society remained ''Pinochetista''.
==Arrest and trial of Pinochet and Lagos administration== {{further|Augusto Pinochet's arrest and trial|Chilean presidential election, 1999-2000}} [[File:Feretro Pinochet.jpg|thumb|Pinochet's funeral.]] Following an agreement between Pinochet and [[Andrés Zaldívar Larraín]], president of the [[Chilean Senate|Senate]], the latter voted to abolish the date of 11 September as a National Holiday which celebrated the 1973 coup. Supporters of Pinochet had blocked until then any such attempt.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/155040.stm Chile abolishes coup holiday], ''[[BBC News]]'', August 20, 1998</ref> The same year, Pinochet traveled to London for an operation. Once there, he [[Augusto Pinochet's arrest and trial|was arrested]] on the orders of Spanish judge [[Baltasar Garzón]], provoking worldwide attention, not only because of the history of Chile and South America, but also because this was one of the first arrest of a dictator based on the [[universal jurisdiction]] principle. Pinochet tried to defend himself by referring to the State Immunity Act of 1978, an argument rejected by British judicial system. However, UK Home Secretary [[Jack Straw]] took the responsibility to release him on medical grounds, and refused to extradite him to Spain. Pinochet returned to Chile in March 2000. Upon descending the plane on his wheelchair, he quickly stood up and saluted the cheering crowd of supporters, including an army band playing his favorite military march tunes, which was awaiting him at the airport in Santiago. President [[Ricardo Lagos]], who had just been sworn in on March 11, said the retired general's televised arrival had damaged the image of Chile, while thousands demonstrated against him.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/665342.stm Thousands march against Pinochet], ''[[BBC]]'', March 4, 2000</ref>
Representing the ''[[Concertación]]'' coalition for democracy, Ricardo Lagos had won [[Chilean presidential election, 1999-2000|the election]] just a few months before, by a very tight score of less than 200,000 votes (51.32%) against [[Joaquín Lavín]] (less than 49%), who represented the right-wing [[Alliance for Chile]]. None of the six candidates had obtained an absolute majority on the first turn held on December 12, 1999. Lagos was sworn-in on March 11, 2000, for a 6-year term.
In June 2000, the Congress voted a new law which granted anonymity to members of the armed forces who provide information on the ''[[desaparecidos]]''.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/807599.stm Soldier confirms Chile stadium killings], ''[[BBC]]'', 27 June 2000 {{en icon}}</ref>
Meanwhile, the trials concerning human rights violations during the dictatorship continued. Pinochet was stripped of his [[parliamentary immunity]] in August 2000 by the [[Chilean Supreme Court|Supreme Court]], and indicted by judge [[Juan Guzmán Tapia]]. Tapia had ordered in 1999 the arrest of five military men, including General Pedro Espinoza Bravo of the [[Dirección de Inteligencia Nacional|DINA]], for their role in the [[Caravan of Death]] following the 11 September coup. Arguing that the bodies of the "[[forced disappearances|disappeared]]" were still missing, he made [[jurisprudence]] which had as effect to lift any [[statute of limitation|prescription]] on the crimes committed by the military. Pinochet's trial continued until his death on December 10, 2006, with an alternance (badword) of indictments for specific cases, lifting of immunities by the Supreme Court or to the contrary immunity from prosecution, with his health a main argument for, or against, his prosecution. The Supreme Court affirmed in March 2005 Pinochet's immunity concerning the 1974 assassination of General [[Carlos Prats]] in Buenos Aires, which had taken place in the frame of [[Operation Condor]]. However, he was deemed fit to stand trial for [[Operation Colombo]], during which 119 political opponents were "disappeared" in Argentina. The Chilean justice also lifted his immunity on the [[Villa Grimaldi]] case, a detention and torture center in the outskirts of Santiago. Pinochet, who still benefited from a reputation of righteousness from his supporters, lost legitimacy when he was put under house arrest on tax fraud and passport forgery, following the publication by the US Senate [[Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations]] of a report concerning the [[Riggs Bank]] in July 2004. The report was a consequence of investigations on financial fundings of the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]] in the US. The bank controlled between USD $4 million and $8 million of Pinochet's assets, who lived in Santiago in a modest house, dissimulating his wealth. According to the report, Riggs participated in [[money laundering]] for Pinochet, setting up offshore [[Shell company|shell corporations]] (referring to Pinochet as only "a former public official"), and hiding his accounts from regulatory agencies. Related to Pinochet's and his family secret bank accounts in United States and in Caraïbs islands, this tax fraud filing for an amount of 27 million dollars shocked the conservative sectors who still supported him. Ninety percent of these funds would have been raised between 1990 and 1998, when Pinochet was chief of the Chilean armies, and would essentially have come from [[weapons traffic]] (when purchasing Belgian 'Mirage' air-fighters in 1994, Dutch 'Léopard' tanks, Swiss 'Mowag' tanks or by illegal sales of weapons to [[Croatia]], in the middle of the [[Balkans war]].) His wife, [[Lucía Hiriart]], and his son, Marco Antonio Pinochet, were also sued for complicity. For the fourth time in seven years, Pinochet was indicted by the Chilean justice.<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2006/US/01/28/chile.pinochet/?section=cnn_topstories U.S. sends back Pinochet daughter], ''[[CNN]]'', January 28, 2006</ref>
The Chilean authorities took control in August 2005 of the [[Colonia Dignidad]] concentration camp, directed by [[ex-Nazi]] [[Paul Schäfer]].
===2005 reform of the 1980 Constitution=== Over 50 reforms to Pinochet's Constitution were approved in 2005, which eliminated some of the remaining undemocratic areas of the text, such as the existence of non-elected Senators (institutional senators, or [[senators for life]]) and the inability of the President to remove the Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces. These reforms led the President to controversially declare Chile's transition to democracy as complete. However, the [[anti-terrorism legislation|anti-terrorist measures]] of it remained in force, and have been used against the [[Mapuche]]s. Furthermore, the military still receives money from the copper industry.
==Bachelet administration== {{See also|Bachelet administration#First presidency (2006–2010)}} In 2006, the ''Concertación'' again won the [[Chilean presidential election, 2005–2006|presidential election]]: [[Michelle Bachelet]], Chile's first woman president, beat [[Sebastián Piñera]] (Alliance for Chile), and obtained more than 53% of the vote. Bachelet's first political crisis occurred with [[2006 student protests in Chile|massive protests by student]], who were demanding free bus fares and the waiving of the university admissions test (PSU) fee, as well as the longer-term demands, which included: the abolition of the Organic Constitutional Law on Teaching (LOCE), an end to municipalization of subsidized education, a reform to the Full-time School Day policy (JEC) and a quality education for all. The protests peaked on May 30, 2006, when 790,000 students adhered to strikes and marches throughout the country, becoming Chile's largest student demonstration of the past three decades.<ref name=NLR>{{Cite journal | last = Riesco | first = Manuel | title = Is Pinochet dead? | journal = [[New Left Review]] | volume = II | issue = 47 | publisher = New Left Review | date = September–October 2007 | url = http://newleftreview.org/II/47/manuel-riesco-is-pinochet-dead | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [http://newleftreview.org/article/download_pdf?language=es&id=2685 Spanish pdf.] [http://newleftreview.org/article/download_pdf?language=it&id=2685 Italian pdf.]</ref>
The [[2006–2007 Chilean corruption scandals]] were a series of events in which the Chilean governing [[Coalition of Parties for Democracy|''Concertación'']] was under investigations of corruption.
In June 2007, General [[Raúl Iturriaga]], the former deputy director of the [[Dirección de Inteligencia Nacional|DINA]], was sentenced to five years' imprisonment for the abduction of Luis Dagoberto San Martin in 1974. Iturriaga had been in hiding from the authorities for a number of years{{Clarify|reason=vague|date=December 2017}} but was arrested in August 2007.<ref name=LAT>{{cite news | last1 = Lagos | first1 = Claudia | last2 = McDonneln | first2 = Patrick J. | title = Pinochet-era general is caught | url = http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-chile3aug03,0,1144327.story?coll=la-home-world | work = [[Los Angeles Times]] | date = August 3, 2007 }}</ref>
The [[CUT (Chile)|CUT]] trade-union federation called for demonstrations in August 2007. These went on during the night, and at least 670 people were arrested (including journalists and a mayor,<ref name=RFI>{{cite web | last = Martin | first = Claire | title = Affrontements violents lors des manifestations anti-Bachelet | url = http://www.rfi.fr/actufr/articles/092/article_55854.asp | website = rfi.fr | publisher = [[Radio France Internationale|RFI]] | location = France | date = 30 August 2007 }}</ref> and 33 ''[[Carabiniers of Chile|carabineros]]'' injured.<ref name=Coop>{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Ultimo balance cifra en 670 los detenidos en jornada de protesta | work = [[Radio Cooperativa]] | date = 30 August 2007 }}</ref> The protests were aimed against the Bachelet's government free market policies. Socialist Senator [[Alejandro Navarro]] was injured by the police during the demonstrations,<ref name=BBC_Demos>{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Clashes erupt at Chilean protests | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/6969439.stm | work = [[BBC News]] | publisher = [[BBC]] | location = London | date = 30 August 2007 }}</ref> although it later emerged that he had hit and kicked police and is currently{{When|date=December 2017}} under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee.<ref>{{cite news | last1 = Vergara | first1 = R. | last2 = Lazaeta | first2 = P. | title = Navarro admite que golpeó dos veces "la mano" del carabinero | work = [[El Mercurio]] | date = 5 September 2007 }}</ref> Senators from the opposition have requested that Navarro and other congressmen who participated in the protest be removed from Congress for violating the constitutional article which bans congressmen from participating demonstrations which "violate the peace".<ref>{{cite news | last = Cisternas | first = Hernán | title = Alianza analiza pedir inhabilidad de Navarro, Aguiló y Enríquez-Ominami | work = [[El Mercurio]] | date = 31 August 2007 }}</ref>
In August 2007, a BBC correspondent wrote that about three million workers, roughly half the workforce, earned the [[minimum wage]] of $260 (£130) a month.<ref name=BBC_Demos/> At the same time, Arturo Martínez, general secretary of the CUT, requested explanations from the government, and accused it of having stirred up the tension.<ref>{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Arturo Martínez acusó al Gobierno de generar clima de violencia | work = [[Radio Cooperativa]] | date = 30 August 2007 }}</ref> Politicians from the center-right ''Alianza'' and from the governing center-left ''Concertación'' have in turn criticized the CUT for the violence of the protest.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}}
==Piñera administration== {{See also|2011–13 Chilean student protests}} {{Expand section|date=January 2015}}

South African celebrities—such as [[Ishmael]], [[Simphiwe Dana]], and [[Lebo Mathosa]]—made [[guest appearance]]s on the show. ==References== *{{cite web |url=http://www.tvsa.co.za/showinfo.asp?showid=2614 |title=Dube on 2 Reloaded |work=TVSA |publisher=Blue Beetle Entertainment |accessdate=3 August 2011}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dube on 2}} [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:South African comedy television series]] [[Category:Television sketch shows]] [[Category:Television talk shows]] [[Category:SABC 2 programmes]] {{SouthAfrica-tv-stub}} {{Comedy-tv-prog-stub}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Bosnia and Herzegovina}} "In the Disco" | image = | caption = | year = 2004 | country = Bosnia and Herzegovina | artist = [[Deen (singer)|Deen]] | as = | with = | language = English | languages = | composer = [[Vesna Pisarović]] | lyricist = [[Vesna Pisarović]] | conductor = | place = 9th | points = 91 | place_semi = 7th | points_semi = 133 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?2004ba Lyrics] | clip = | prev = Ne brini | prev_link = Ne brini | next = Call Me | next_link = Call Me (Feminnem song) }} [[File:Deen.jpg|157px|thumb|left|[[Deen (singer)|Deen]] performing "In the Disco" for [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]].]] '''"In the Disco"''' was the [[Bosnia and Herzegovina in the Eurovision Song Contest|Bosnia-Herzegovinian]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2004]], performed entirely in [[English Language|English]] (the first time the country had not sung at least partly in one of its official languages) by [[Deen (singer)|Deen]].
As Bosnia had not finished in the top ten in the previous Contest, the song was performed in the semi-final. Here, it was performed twenty-first (following [[Serbia and Montenegro]]'s [[Željko Joksimović]] & [[Ad Hoc Orchestra]] with "[[Lane Moje]]" and preceding the [[Netherlands]]'s [[Re-Union]] with "[[Without You (Eurovision song)|Without You]]"). It received 133 points to place 7th in the 22-song semi-final and qualify for the final.<ref>[http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=9 Eurovision Semi-Final 2004 Scoreboard]. Eurovision.tv. Retrieved 30.07.2011</ref>
In the final, it was performed twelfth (following [[Croatia]]'s [[Ivan Mikulić]] with [[You Are the Only One (Ivan Mikulić song)|You Are The Only One]] and preceding [[Belgium]]'s [[Xandee]] with "[[1 Life]]"). At the close of voting, it had received 91 points, placing 9th in a field of 24 and qualifying Bosnia for the final at the next Contest.<ref>[http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=8 Eurovision Final 2004 Scoreboard]. Eurovision.tv. Retrieved 30.07.2011</ref>
The song is an up-tempo Eurodisco number, with Deen expressing his desire to "stay all night, in the disco".<ref>[http://diggiloo.net/?2004ba "In the Disco" Lyrics]. Diggiloo Thrush. Retrieved 30.07.2011</ref>
It was succeeded as [[Bosnia and Herzegovina in the Eurovision Song Contest|Bosnian and Herzegovinian representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2005|2005 Contest]] by [[Feminnem]] with "[[Call Me (Feminnem song)|Call Me]]".
{{Bosnia and Herzegovina in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 2004}}
<references />

revision.text:
{{Infobox spaceflight | name = Intelsat 29e | names_list = '''IS-29e''' | image = | image_caption = | image_alt = | image_size = | mission_type = [[Communications satellite|Communication]] | operator = [[Intelsat]] | Harvard_designation = | COSPAR_ID = 2016-004A | SATCAT = 41308 | website = [http://www.intelsat.com/fleetmaps/?s=IS-29e Intelsat IS-29e] | mission_duration = | spacecraft = IS-29e | spacecraft_type = | spacecraft_bus = [[Boeing 702|Boeing 702MP]] | manufacturer = [[Boeing Satellite Development Center|Boeing]] | launch_mass = {{convert|6552|kg|abbr=on}} | BOL_mass = | landing_mass = | dry_mass = | payload_mass = | dimensions = {{convert|7.5|x|3|x|2|m}} | power = 15.8 kW | launch_date = {{start date|2016|01|27|23|20|7=Z}} | launch_rocket = [[Ariane 5 ECA]] VA-228 | launch_site = [[Guiana Space Center|GSC]] [[ELA-3]] | launch_contractor = [[Arianespace]] | deployment_from = | deployment_date = | entered_service = | disposal_type = | deactivated = | destroyed = | last_contact = | recovery_by = | recovery_date = | decay_date = | landing_date = | landing_site = | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Geosynchronous orbit|Geosynchronous]] | orbit_longitude = [[50th meridian west|50° West]] | orbit_slot = | orbit_semimajor = {{convert|42,241.0|km|mi}} | orbit_eccentricity = | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|35,864.3|km|mi}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|35,875.9|km|mi}} | orbit_inclination = 0.0° | orbit_period = 1,440 minutes | orbit_RAAN = | orbit_arg_periapsis = | orbit_mean_anomaly = | orbit_mean_motion = | orbit_repeat = | orbit_velocity = | orbit_epoch = | orbit_rev_number = | apsis = gee | trans_band = [[High-throughput satellite|High throughput]]
[[C band (IEEE)|C band]]: 20
[[Ku band|Ku band]]: 56
[[Ka band|Ka band]]: 1 | trans_frequency = | trans_bandwidth = [[C band (IEEE)|C band]]: 864 MHz
[[Ku band|Ku band]]: 9,395 MHz
[[Ka band|Ka band]]: 450 MHz | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = [[CONUS]], [[Latin America]] and [[North America]] | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = | programme = [[Intelsat|EpicNG]] | previous_mission = | next_mission = [[Intelsat 33e]] | insignia = | insignia_caption = | insignia_alt = | insignia_size = }} '''Intelsat 29e''', also known as '''IS-29e''' is a [[High-throughput satellite|high throughput]] [[geostationary orbit|geostationary]] [[communications satellite]] designed and manufactured by [[Boeing Satellite Development Center|Boeing]] on the [[Boeing 702|BSS-702MP]] platform. It is the first satellite of the EpicNG service, and covers [[CONUS]], Latin America and North America from the [[50th meridian west|50° West]] longitude, where it is replaced [[Intelsat 1R]]. It also replaced [[Intelsat 805]] which was moved from [[56th meridian west|56.5° West]] to [[169th meridian east|169° East]]. It has a mixed [[C band (IEEE)|C band]], [[Ku band|Ku band]] and [[Ka band|Ka band]] payload with all bands featuring wide and the Ku also featuring spot beams. ==Satellite description== The spacecraft was designed and manufactured by [[Boeing Satellite Development Center|Boeing]] on the [[Boeing 702]]MP [[satellite bus]]. It has a launch mass of {{convert|6,552|kg|abbr=on}} and a design life of more than 15 years. When stowed for launch, the satellite measures {{convert|7.5|x|3|x|2|m|abbr=on}}. It is powered by two wings, with four panels each, of [[Triple-junction solar cell|triple-junction]] [[Gallium arsenide|GsAs]] [[solar cell]]s, that span {{convert|44|m|abbr=on}} when deployed. Intelsat 29e can generate 15.8 Kw at the end of its expected life and has four [[Lithium-ion battery|Li-ion]] batteries. This [[Three-axis stabilisation|three axis stabilized]] platform has a [[Bipropellant rocket|bi-propellant propulsion]] system using [[Nitrogen tetroxide|NTO]]/[[Dinitrogen tetroxide|N2O4]]. It has a {{convert|449|N|abbr=on}} [[Liquid Apogee Engine]] for [[Orbital maneuver|orbit raising]] and {{convert|22|N|abbr=on}} and {{convert|4|N|abbr=on}} thrusters for [[Orbital station-keeping|station keeping]]. The propellant tanks hold approximately {{convert|1550|kg|abbr=on}} of N2O4 and {{convert|2000|kg|abbr=on}} of NTO. This new series of geosynchronous satellites lack an [[Attitude control#Earth sensor|Earth Sensor]], and thus enter Earth pointing attitude based on the orbital position as determined by the [[star tracker]]. Its payload is the first [[High-throughput satellite|high throughput]] EpicNG deployment, of the six planned as of January 2016. The EpicNG is characterized by the implementation of frequency reuse due to a mix of frequency and polarization in small spot beams. Not only applied to the classical [[High-throughput satellite|HTS]] [[Ka band|Ka band]], but also applying the same technique in [[Ku band|Ku band]] and [[C band (IEEE)|C band]]. The EpicNG series also keep the use of wide beams to offer high throughput and broadcast capabilities in the same satellite. The payload is designed and manufactured by Boeing based on the work of the [[Wideband Global SATCOM|WGS]] constellation. It most innovative feature of this fully digital payload, is that it enables to dynamically link two sites through a single satellite without needing to go through a ground station. In the case of Intelsat 29e, the C band side has 14 physical [[Transponder (satellite communications)|transponders]] with a bandwidth 864 MHz Ku or 24 [[transponder equivalent]]. It covers South America in a wide beam. The Ku band has physical 56 transponders (249 transponder equivalent) for a total bandwidth of 9,395 MHz. The Ku spot beams cover the Americas and the North Atlantic route, while a wide beam can broadcast to North America and North Atlantic. The Ka band payload has 450 MHz of bandwidth on a global beam centered at its position. ==History== In July 2009, [[Intelsat]] became the first customer of the [[Boeing 702|Boeing 702MP]] platform, when it place an order for four spacecrafts, [[Intelsat 21]], [[Intelsat 22]], [[Intelsat 27]] and what would become '''Intelsat 29e'''. On June 7, 2012, Intelsat announced the EpicNG platform. It would improve available bandwidth due to the use of frequency reuse and polarization and feature spot and wide beams, enabling high bandwidth and broadcast applications on a backward compatible way. The first two satellites would be Intelsat 29e and Intelsat 33e. On September 4, 2012, Intelsat and Boeing announced that Intelsat 29e, the first EpicNG satellite, would be made by Boeing on the 702MP platform, completing the 2009 order of four such satellites. In May 2013 Intelsat ordered a further four 702MP-based EpicNG satellites, [[Intelsat 32e]], [[Intelsat 33e]] and two as of August 2016 unnamed spacecraft. And in July 2014 a sixth Epic was ordered, [[Intelsat 35e]]. During 2013, Intelsat signed a contract to launch Intelsat 29e aboard an [[Ariane 5]]. Brian Sing, was assigned as Senior Program Manager for the launch aboard the rocket. During June 2015, the payload was integrated and went through testing. First it was deployed and stowed back, then it went through [[Environmental noise|sound environment]] and [[Shaker (testing device)|vibration testing]], and finally deployment was tested again. On July 14, 2015, the payload integration to the [[satellite bus]] and its non-environmental testing was completed. It would then go through the [[Environmental tests|environmental testing]] campaign which would start with [[thermal vacuum chamber]] tests. It is a Boeing design based on the work of the [[Wideband Global SATCOM|WGS]] constellation. On December 10, 2015, Intelsat announced that the launch date for Intelsat 29e had been set for January 27, 2016. After four years of project development, Intelsat 29e arrived to the launch site aboard an [[Antonov 124]] on December 11, 2015. At the site's Payload Processing Facility, Boeing technicians unpackaged the spacecraft and associated equipment and performed a quick fit check. On the second weeks of January, 2016, the satellite was fueled and installed in the rocket payload adapter. By January 21, the spacecraft had been moved to the Final Assembly Building where it was mated to the launcher rocket. On January 26, 2016 all checks were completed and the launch review for the next day was completed. On January 27, 2016, at 23:20 UTC, an [[Ariane 5 ECA]] launched from the [[ELA-3]] launch pad at the [[Guiana Space Center]]. Intelsat 29e, its only passenger, separated 30 minutes later, and the satellite first signals were received shortly afterwards by the Kumsan, South Korea, Ground Station. The next two days were spent evaluating the health of the satellite and determining the exact orbit, then a series of nine orbital maneuvers to raise the perigee to {{convert|35,786|km|abbr=on}} were started. This orbit circularization would consume approximately {{convert|2500|kg|abbr=on}} of propellant. When it reached its test position at 49.7° West, it deployed its antennas and solar panels. In a March 28, 2016 blog by Duy Nguyen, Senior Program Manager, it was announced that Intelsat 29e had successfully passed the 30-day payload in-orbit testing (PIOT) and was undergoing the first performance testing with an anchor customer. It had been particularly challenging because it was the first digital configurable payload for Intelsat, and they had to also test the ground segment for the first time. ==References== {{Reflist|2|refs= {{cite web |url=http://www.space-airbusds.com/media/document/dossier-de-vol-v228-e.pdf |title=Ariane 5 Data relating to flight 228 |publisher=[[Arianespace]] |format=PDF |date=January 2016 |access-date=2016-08-24}} {{cite web |url=http://www.arianespace.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/Dossier-de-presse-VA-228-final-GB.pdf |title=Launch Kit VA228 |publisher=[[Arianespace]] |format=PDF |date=January 2016 |access-date=2016-08-24}} {{cite web |url=http://www.boeing.com/resources/boeingdotcom/space/boeing_satellite_family/pdf/Bkgrd_Intelsat.pdf |title=Intelsat |publisher=[[Boeing]] |format=PDF |date=October 2015 |access-date=2016-08-24}} {{cite web |url=http://boeing.mediaroom.com/2016-01-27-Boeing-built-Intelsat-29e-Satellite-Begins-New-Intelsat-Constellation |title=Boeing-built Intelsat 29e Satellite Begins New Intelsat Constellation revision.text:
{{Unreferenced stub|auto=yes|date=December 2009}} The '''''Jacobstads Wapen''''' is a modern [[Ship replica|replica]] of an 18th-century [[galeas]] built in [[Jakobstad]], Finland, between 1988 and 1994. She is built according to blueprints by the Swedish warship architect [[Fredrik Henrik af Chapman]] dating from 1755, the oldest vessel blueprints found in Finland. She is classified by the Finnish national board of navigation as a passenger, special-purpose vessel. The 18th century galleon ''Jacobstads Wapen'' was sold off in [[Amsterdam]].
She has been used as a symbol for Jakobstad but as of late has encountered financial problems. She participated in the festivities at the 300 year anniversary of [[Saint Petersburg|St. Petersburg]], Russia, in 2003. In 2005 it was discovered that some of the woodwork had deteriorated and is currently awaiting renovations.
==Specifications== * Length: 82 ft (25 meters) * Length (overall): 131 ft (40 meters) * Bowsprit: 49 ft (15 meters) * Width: 25 ft (7.6 meters) * Draught: 8 ft (2.5 meters) * Sails: eight, total sail area 5 813sq/ft (540 square meters) * Main mast height: 105 ft (32 meters) above the waterline * Engines: 700 hp [[Volvo Penta]] * Ballast: 34.4 long tons (35 metric tons) * Speed: between 0 and 10 knots (often around 7 knots) under sail.
==See also== *[[Jakobstad]] *[[Sailing ships]] *[[Ship replica]]
==External links== *[http://www.tugboatlars.se/JacobstadsWapen.htm Photos of Jacobstads Wapen]
[[Category:Ships of Finland]] [[Category:Ships built in Finland]] [[Category:Jakobstad]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Ostrobothnia (region)]] [[Category:Replica ships]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox airport | name = Juneau International Airport | image = JNU-a.jpg | image-width = 250 | IATA = JNU | ICAO = PAJN | FAA = JNU | WMO = 70381 | type = Public | owner = City of Juneau | operator = | city-served = [[Juneau, Alaska]] | location = | hub = [[Alaska Seaplanes]] | elevation-f = 25 | elevation-m = 8 | website = {{URL|www.juneau.org/airport/|Juneau.org/airport}} | coordinates = {{coord|58|21|18|N|134|34|35|W|region:US-AK|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = USA Alaska | pushpin_relief = yes | pushpin_mapsize = 250 | pushpin_map_caption = Location of airport in Alaska | pushpin_label = '''JNU''' | pushpin_label_position = bottom | r1-number = 8/26 | r1-length-f = 8,857 | r1-length-m = 2,700 | r1-surface = Asphalt | r2-number = 8W/26W | r2-length-f = 4,600 | r2-length-m = 1,402 | r2-surface = Water | stat-year = 2017 | stat1-header = Aircraft operations | stat1-data = 108,885 | stat2-header = Based aircraft | stat2-data = 275 | footnotes = Source: [[Federal Aviation Administration]]{{FAA-airport|ID=JNU|use=PU|own=PU|site=50385.*A}}. Federal Aviation Administration. effective August 25, 2011. }} '''Juneau International Airport''' {{Airport codes|JNU|PAJN|JNU}} is a city-owned, public-use airport and [[seaplane]] base located seven [[nautical mile]]s (8 mi, 13 km) northwest of the central business district of [[Juneau, Alaska|Juneau]], a city and [[boroughs of Alaska|borough]] in the U.S. state of [[Alaska]] that has no direct road access to the outside world. The airport serves as a regional hub for all air travel, from bush carriers to a major U.S. air carrier, [[Alaska Airlines]]. The [[National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems]] for 2015-2019 [[FAA airport categories|categorized]] it as a ''primary commercial service (nonhub)'' airport based on 353,048 enplanements (boardings) in 2012. {{cite web |url=http://www.faa.gov/airports/planning_capacity/npias/reports/media/npias-2015-2019-report-appendix-a.pdf |title=Appendix A: List of NPIAS Airports with 5-Year Forecast Activity and Development Estimate |website=National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems (NPIAS) Report |publisher=Federal Aviation Administration |format=PDF |access-date=May 23, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160222040927/http://www.faa.gov/airports/planning_capacity/npias/reports/media/npias-2015-2019-report-appendix-a.pdf |archivedate=February 22, 2016 |df= }} As per the [[Federal Aviation Administration]], this airport had 378,741 passenger enplanements in [[calendar year]] 2008, {{cite web | url = http://www.faa.gov/airports/planning_capacity/passenger_allcargo_stats/passenger/media/cy08_all_enplanements.pdf | title = Enplanements for CY 2008 | format = PDF, 1.0 MB | work = [http://www.faa.gov/airports/planning_capacity/passenger_allcargo_stats/passenger/index.cfm?year=2008 CY 2008 Passenger Boarding and All-Cargo Data] | publisher = Federal Aviation Administration | date = December 18, 2009 }} 337,038 in 2009, and 344,057 in 2010. {{cite web | url = http://www.faa.gov/airports/planning_capacity/passenger_allcargo_stats/passenger/media/cy10_all_enplanements.pdf | title = Enplanements for CY 2010 | format = PDF, 189 KB | work = [http://www.faa.gov/airports/planning_capacity/passenger_allcargo_stats/passenger/index.cfm?year=2010 CY 2010 Passenger Boarding and All-Cargo Data] | publisher = Federal Aviation Administration | date = October 4, 2011 }} ==History== During [[World War II]], Juneau Airport was used by the [[United States Army Air Forces]] as a transport link between the combat bases being established in the Aleutians and airfields in the Continental United States. It was also used by [[Air Transport Command (United States Air Force)|Air Transport Command]] and facilitated the transport of [[Lend-Lease]] aircraft to the [[Soviet Union]] via [[Nome, Alaska|Nome]] ([[Marks Army Airfield]]).{{Air Force Historical Research Agency}} ===Historical airline service=== [[Pan American World Airways]] ([[Pan Am]]) was one of the first major airlines to serve Juneau. In 1947, Pan Am was operating daily [[Douglas DC-4]] propliner service to [[Seattle]] via a stop at the [[Annette Island Airport]], which served [[Ketchikan]] at the time and also flew DC-4 service twice a week nonstop to [[Whitehorse, Yukon|Whitehorse]] in the [[Yukon Territory]] of [[Canada]] with continuing, no change of plane service to [[Fairbanks]], [[Galena]] and [[Nome, Alaska|Nome]] in Alaska.http://www.timetableimages.com, Nov. 1, 1947 Pan American World Airways system timetable. Pan Am later operated [[Douglas DC-6B]] and [[Boeing 377 Stratocruiser]] aircraft into the airport.http://www.sitnews.com During the 1950s, [[Pacific Northern Airlines]] served the airport with [[Douglas DC-4]] and [[Lockheed Constellation]] propliners with daily service to Seattle via a stop at Annette Island as well as nonstop to [[Anchorage]] and [[Yakutat, Alaska|Yakutat]] and direct to [[Cordova, Alaska|Cordova]] in Alaska.http://www.timetableimages.com, Sept. 2, 1958 Pacific Northern Airlines system timetable The jet age arrived in Juneau during the early 1960s. In 1963, Pan Am was operating daily [[Boeing 707]] jetliner flights to Seattle via a stop at Annette Island.http://www.timetableimages.com, Aug. 1, 1963 Pan American World Airways system timetable By 1965, Pacific Northern was operating [[Boeing 720]] jets nonstop to Seattle, Anchorage and Annette Island.http://www.timetableimages.com, Oct. 1, 1965 Pacific Northern Airlines system timetable In 1967, Pacific Northern was acquired by and merged into [[Western Airlines]], which continued to operate jet service into the airport.http://www.timetablemages.com{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Aug. 1, 1967 Pacific Northern Airlines (a division of Western Airlines) system timetable By 1968, Western was operating daily nonstop [[Boeing 720B]] jet service to Seattle, Anchorage and Annette Island with one stop direct service to [[Los Angeles]].http://www.timetableimages.com, Aug. 1, 1968 Western Airlines system timetable By 1969, [[Alaska Airlines]] was operating [[Boeing 727-100]] jet service into the airport on a daily basis with a round trip routing of Seattle - [[Sitka, Alaska|Sitka]] - Juneau - Yakutat - Cordova - Anchorage - [[Unalakleet]] - Nome - [[Kotzebue]].http://www.timetableimages.com, Summer-Fall 1969 Alaska Airlines system timetable Alaska Air has served Juneau for over 45 years and primarily operated [[Boeing 727-100]], [[727-200]] and [[737-200]] jetliners into the airport (including the [[Boeing 737-200]] passenger/freight [[Combi aircraft]]) in addition to [[Boeing 720]] jetliners before switching to later model [[Boeing 737]] jets."Alaska Airlines" by Cliff & Nancy Hollenbeck, www.hollenbeckproductions.com Besides operating jet service into Juneau, Alaska Airlines also flew smaller prop and turboprop aircraft from the airport in the past including the [[Convair 240]], [[de Havilland Canada DHC-6 Twin Otter]] and two versions of the [[Grumman Goose]] [[amphibian aircraft]], being a piston powered model and a turboprop version with the latter being named the "Turbo-Goose" by the airline. Alaska Airlines began serving Juneau during the late 1960s following its acquisition of two local air service carriers, [[Alaska Coastal Airlines]], which was based in Juneau, and Cordova Airlines.[[File:Juneau International Airport Main Terminal and Control Tower.jpg|thumb|250px|Closeup view of the airport's main terminal, including both older and newer [[control tower]]s. [[Mendenhall Glacier]] is seen in the background.]]Other air carriers that served Juneau over the years included [[Wien Air Alaska]] and [[MarkAir]], which had both been based in Alaska. [[Western Airlines]] also returned to Juneau after ceasing service during the early 1970s.http://www.departedflights.com, April 30, 1972 Western Airlines route map In 1968, Wien was operating [[Fairchild F-27]] turboprop flights into the airport three days a week on a routing of Juneau - Whitehorse - Fairbanks.http://www.timetableimages.com, Sept. 16, 1968 Wien Air Alaska system timetable By 1977, Wien was flying [[Boeing 737-200]] jet service twice a week from the airport on a routing of Juneau - Whitehorse - Fairbanks - Anchorage and by 1979 the airline was operating daily nonstop 737-200 jet flights to Seattle and Anchorage.http://www.timetableimages.com, Sept. 15, 1977 Wien Air Alaska system timetablehttp://www.departedflights.com, Nov. 15, 1979 Official Airline Guide (OAG), Seattle-Juneau & Anchorage-Juneau schedules During the early and mid 1980s, Western was operating daily nonstop [[Boeing 727-200]] service to Seattle.http://www.departedflights.com, April 1, 1983 & Feb. 15, 1985 Official Airline Guide (OAG) editions, Seattle-Juneau schedules Following its acquisition of and merger with Western in 1987, [[Delta Air Lines]] continued to serve Juneau with daily nonstop [[Boeing 727-200]] flights to Seattle and direct, one stop service to Los Angeles into the early 1990s.http://www.departedflights.com, Dec. 15, 1989 & Oct. 1, 1991 Official Airline Guide (OAG) editions, Seattle-Juneau schedules In 1995, MarkAir operated daily nonstop [[Boeing 737-400]] jet service to Seattle and Anchorage.http://www.departedflights.com, April 2, 1995 Official Airline Guide (OAG), Seattle-Juneau & Anchorage-Juneau schedules In 2014, [[Delta Air Lines]] returned to Juneau offering first seasonal, and then year round service before leaving the market again at the end of 2016 and now serves Juneau on a seasonal basis. Delta entering the market to compete with Alaska Air resulted in fares to Seattle being reduced almost by half.{{cite web |url=http://juneauempire.com/local/2016-04-11/delta-end-year-round-service-juneau |title=Delta to end year-round service in Juneau |last=Phu |first=Lisa |publisher=Juneau Empire |date=April 11, 2016 |website=JuneauEmprie.com |access-date=August 23, 2017}} ==Facilities and aircraft== [[File:Juneau Terminal.jpg|thumb|The main passenger terminal at Juneau International Airport]] Juneau International Airport covers an area of 662 acres (268 [[hectare|ha]]) at an elevation of 25 feet (8 m) above [[mean sea level]]. It has one [[runway]] designated 8/26 with an [[asphalt]] surface measuring 8,857 by 150 feet (2,700 x 46 m). It also has one [[seaplane]] landing area designated 8W/26W, which measures 4,600 by 150 feet (1,402 x 46 m). For the 12-month period ending December 31, 2017, the airport had 108,885 aircraft operations, an average of 298 per day: 79% [[air taxi]], 12% [[general aviation]], 8% [[airline|scheduled commercial]], and <1% [[military aviation|military]]. At that time 275 aircraft were based at this airport: 87% single-[[aircraft engine|engine]], 1% multi-engine, <1% [[jet aircraft|jet]], 10% [[helicopter]], and 1% [[military aircraft|military]]. [[File:Alaska 738 PAJN.jpg|thumb|An [[Alaska Airlines]] [[Boeing 737 Next Generation|Boeing 737-800]] taxiing to the terminal at Juneau International Airport.]] ==Airlines and destinations== Aside from providing passenger service, [[Alaska Airlines]] also operates [[Boeing 737 Next Generation|Boeing 737-700]] jet freighter cargo flight service into Juneau.http://www.alaskaair.com/content/cargo-home, Freighter and Combi Schedule ===Passenger=== {{Airport destination list | [[Alaska Airlines]] | [[Ted Stevens Anchorage International Airport|Anchorage]], [[Merle K. (Mudhole) Smith Airport|Cordova]], [[Ketchikan International Airport|Ketchikan]], [[Petersburg James A. Johnson Airport|Petersburg]], [[Seattle–Tacoma International Airport|Seattle/Tacoma]], [[Sitka Rocky Gutierrez Airport|Sitka]], [[Wrangell Airport|Wrangell]], [[Yakutat Airport|Yakutat]]
'''Seasonal:''' [[Gustavus Airport|Gustavus]] |Alaska Seaplanes| [[Angoon Seaplane Base|Angoon]], [[Elfin Cove Seaplane Base|Elfin Cove]], [[Excursion Inlet Seaplane Base|Excursion Inlet]], [[Gustavus Airport|Gustavus]], [[Haines Airport|Haines]], [[Hoonah Airport|Hoonah]], [[Kake Seaplane Base|Kake]], [[Sitka Rocky Gutierrez Airport|Sitka]], [[Skagway Airport|Skagway]], [[Pelican Seaplane Base|Pelican]], [[Tenakee Seaplane Base|Tenakee Springs]], [[Erik Nielsen Whitehorse International Airport|Whitehorse]] | [[Delta Air Lines]] | '''Seasonal:''' [[Seattle–Tacoma International Airport|Seattle/Tacoma]] | Harris Air | [[Sitka Rocky Gutierrez Airport|Sitka]], [[Gustavus Airport|Gustavus]] | Island Air Express | [[Ketchikan International Airport|Ketchikan]], [[Petersburg James A. Johnson Airport|Petersburg]], [[Klawock Airport|Klawock]] | Ward Air| Charter: [[Chatham Seaplane Base|Chatham]], [[Funter Bay Seaplane Base|Funter Bay]] }} [[File:JNU1.jpg|thumb|An [[Alaska Airlines]] [[Boeing 737-400|Boeing 737-400C]] being loaded with cargo at Juneau International Airport.]] ===Cargo=== {| class="wikitable" !Airline !Destinations |- | [[Alaska Air Group|Alaska Air Cargo]] | [[Ted Stevens Anchorage International Airport|Anchorage]], [[Seattle–Tacoma International Airport|Seattle/Tacoma]] |- | [[Alaska Central Express]] | [[Ted Stevens Anchorage International Airport|Anchorage]], [[Ketchikan International Airport|Ketchikan]] |- | [[Empire Airlines]] | [[Ted Stevens Anchorage International Airport|Anchorage]] |} ==Statistics== {{Bar graph | title = Carrier shares for (Dec 2015 – Nov 2016) | bar_width = 20 | width_units = em | label_type = Carrier | data_type = Passengers (enplaned + deplaned) | data_max = 574,000 | label1 = Alaska | data1 = 574,000 | comment1 = 84.55% | label2 = Kalinin | data2 = 55,190 | comment2 = 8.13% | label3 = Delta | data3 = 44,990 | comment3 = 6.62% | label5 = Ward Air | data5 = 60 | comment5 = 0.01% | label4 = Air Excursions | data4 = 4,700 | comment4 = 0.69% | label6 = Other | data6 = 30 | comment6 = 0.00% }} ===Top destinations=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ '''Busiest domestic routes from JNU
(Dec 2015 – Nov 2016)''' {{cite web | url = http://www.transtats.bts.gov/airports.asp?pn=1&Airport=JNU&End_YearMonth=24202 | title = Juneau, AK: Juneau International (JNU) | publisher = [[Bureau of Transportation Statistics]] | date = July 2011 }} ! Rank ! City ! Passengers ! Airline |- | 1 | [[Seattle–Tacoma International Airport|Seattle/Tacoma, Washington]] | 175,000 | Alaska, Delta |- | 2 | [[Ted Stevens Anchorage International Airport|Anchorage, Alaska]] | 76,000 | Alaska |- | 3 | [[Sitka Rocky Gutierrez Airport|Sitka, Alaska]] | 22,000 | Alaska, Alaska Seaplanes |- | 4 | [[Ketchikan International Airport|Ketchikan, Alaska]] | 17,000 | Alaska |- | 5 | [[Petersburg James A. Johnson Airport|Petersburg, Alaska]] | 10,000 | Alaska |- | 6 | [[Haines Airport|Haines, Alaska]] | 7,000 | Air Excursions, Alaska Seaplanes, Wings of Alaska |- | 6 | [[Hoonah Airport|Hoonah, Alaska]] | 7,000 | Air Excursions, Alaska Seaplanes, Wings of Alaska |- | 8 | [[Gustavus Airport|Gustavus, Alaska]] | 6,000 | Air Excursions, Alaska, Alaska Seaplanes, Wings of Alaska |- | 9 | [[Skagway Airport|Skagway, Alaska]] | 5,000 | Air Excursions, Alaska Seaplanes, Wings of Alaska |- | 10 | [[Yakutat Airport|Yakutat, Alaska]] | 4,000 | Alaska |} ==Location and controversy== {{Unreferenced section|date=October 2011}} [[File:JNU2.jpg|thumb|An [[Alaska Airlines]] [[Boeing 737-400|Boeing 737-400C]] at Juneau International Airport.]] Because of the extreme geography of Southeastern [[Alaska]], land flat enough for airport facilities is at a premium. One of these few areas is the current location of the airport: the Mendenhall Wetlands State Game Refuge, a vastly diverse and ecologically critical region rich with plant life, small mammals, birds, several species of salmon, even [[American black bear|black bear]]s and [[bald eagle]]s. The original airstrip was built in the 1930s, and no environmental impact analysis was performed at that time. The area currently housing the terminal and runways had to be filled in and part of the [[Gastineau Channel]] had to be dredged before the airport, in its current incarnation, could be built. The airport is the only way in and out of the city, with exception of the [[Alaska Marine Highway]] and cargo ships traversing the [[Inside Passage]]. In the past, concerns have been raised over the safety of the airport, which is comparatively quite small, with the amount of air traffic it receives. In addition to frequent arrivals and departures from hubs such as [[Anchorage, Alaska|Anchorage]] and [[Seattle, Washington|Seattle/Tacoma]], the airport also has daily and/or weekly service to smaller regional communities, a [[floatplane]] runway/docking area, and a [[heliport]]. Three major construction projects are planned at the airport within the next few years. An airport terminal renovation project will be the first comprehensive upgrade to the passenger facilities in over twenty years and will provide for better flow through the passenger screening process. The airfield maintenance facilities project will provide much needed room for storage and servicing of snow removal equipment. The runway safety area project will extend the runway at both ends and improve taxiways to meet Federal Aviation Administration requirements. ==Accidents and incidents== On September 4, 1971, [[Alaska Airlines Flight 1866]], a [[Boeing 727-100]], crashed into the easterly slope of a canyon in the Chilkat Range of the [[Tongass National Forest]] while on approach to Juneau International Airport. All 111 passengers and crew on board were killed. At the time it was the worst single airplane air disaster in United States history.{{Cite news|last=Kiffer|first=Dave|date=September 7, 2011|title=40 Years ago, 111 died in Alaska Airlines Crash Near Juneau|url=http://www.sitnews.us/Kiffer/AlaskaAirJuneau/090711_ak_airlines_crash.html|newspaper=Stories in the News|location=[[Ketchikan]]|access-date=May 25, 2016}} ==See also== * [[Alaska World War II Army Airfields]] * [[List of airports in Alaska]] {{Portalbar|Alaska|Aviation|Military of the United States|United States Air Force}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em|refs=}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * [http://www.juneau.org/airport Juneau International Airport], official web site * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090114053624/http://www.alaska.faa.gov/fai/images/ARPT_DIAGRAMS/JNU.gif FAA Alaska airport diagram for Juneau International (JNU)] ([[GIF]]) * [http://msrmaps.com/map.aspx?t=2&s=13&lat=58.355&lon=-134.5763&w=500&h=500&lp=---+None+--- Topographic map] from [[USGS]] ''[[The National Map]]'' * {{FAA-diagram|01191|Juneau International (JNU)}} * {{FAA-procedures|JNU|Juneau International (JNU)}} {{US-airport2|JNU|PAJN}} ** {{FAA-delay|JNU}} {{USAAF 11th Air Force World War II}} [[Category:Airfields of the United States Army Air Forces in Alaska]] [[Category:Airports in Alaska]] [[Category:Transportation buildings and structures in Juneau, Alaska]] [[Category:WAAS reference stations]]

page.title: List of countries and dependencies by population

revision.comment: /* Sovereign states and dependencies by population */
revision.text:
[[File:Countries and Dependencies by Population in 2014.svg|thumb|upright=1.36|A map of world population in 2014]] [[File:World population percentage.png|thumb|right|World population percentage by country as of 2017.]] [[File:World Population Cartogram Map 2002.tif|thumb|A [[cartogram]] of the world population in 2002.]] This is a list of [[country|countries]] and [[dependent territory|dependent territories]] by [[population]]. It includes [[list of sovereign states|sovereign states]], inhabited [[dependent territory|dependent territories]] and, in some cases, constituent countries of sovereign states, with inclusion within the list being primarily based on the ISO standard [[ISO 3166-1]]. For instance, the [[United Kingdom]] is considered as a single entity while the constituent countries of the [[Kingdom of the Netherlands]] are considered separately. In addition, this list includes certain [[list of states with limited recognition|states with limited recognition]] not found in ISO 3166-1. Also given in percent is each country's population compared with the [[World population|population of the world]], which the [[United Nations]] estimates at {{#expr: {{worldpop}}/1000000000 round 2}} billion as of today. ==Method== {{See also|List of countries and territories by population density|List of regional organizations by population}} Figures used in this chart are based on the most up to date [[Population projection|estimate or projections]]{{cite journal | url=http://www.economist.com/node/18651512 | title=China's Population: The Most Surprising Demographic Crisis |journal=The Economist |year=2013}} by the national [[census]] authority where available, and are usually rounded off. Where updated national data are not available, figures are based on the projections for 2018 by the Population Division of the [[United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs]].{{cite web | url=https://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp/DataQuery/ | title=World Population Prospects 2018}} Because the compiled figures are not collected at the same time in every country, or at the same level of [[statistics|accuracy]], the resulting numerical comparisons may create misleading conclusions. Furthermore, the addition of figures from all countries may not equal the world total. A handful of nations have not conducted a census in over 30 years, providing high error margin estimates only. Areas that form integral parts of sovereign states, such as the [[countries of the United Kingdom]], are counted as part of the sovereign states concerned. Not included are other entities, such as the [[European Union]],The European Union is a ''[[sui generis]]'' [[supranational union]] whose sovereign members delegate to it by treaty certain powers that are often exercised by sovereign states. Its combined population has been estimated at 510,284,430 on January 1, 2016, and it would be ranked 3rd if it were included in the list. It has {{#expr: 510284430 / {{worldpop}} * 100 round 2}}% of the world's population — see {{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/tgm/table.do?tab=table&language=en&pcode=tps00001&tableSelection=1&footnotes=yes&labeling=labels&plugin=1|title=Eurostat-Tables, Graphs and Maps Interface（TGM）table|publisher=[[European Commission]]}} that are not sovereign states, and independent territories that do not have permanent populations, such as [[Territorial claims in Antarctica|various countries' claims]] to [[Antarctica]]. ==Sovereign states and dependencies by population== Note: All dependent territories or constituent countries that are parts of sovereign states are shown in ''italics'' and not assigned a numbered rank. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:right" |- !data-sort-type="number" | Rank !! Country
(or dependent territory) !! Population !! Date !! % of world

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Michele Cachia | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1760|09|30|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Żejtun]], [[History of Malta under the Order of Saint John|Malta]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1839|01|24|1760|09|30|df=y}} | death_place = | nationality = Maltese | occupation = Architect
Military engineer | father = Gio Maria Cachia | relatives = [[Antonio Cachia]] (cousin) | module = {{Infobox military person|embed=yes | allegiance = {{Flagicon|SMOM}} [[Knights Hospitaller|Order of Saint John]]
{{flagicon image|Unofficial Flag of Malta (pre-1943).svg}} [[Malta]] | branch = Żejtun militia
[[National Congress Battalions]] | battles = [[Siege of Malta (1798–1800)]] | serviceyears = | rank = }} }} [[File:Malta - Siggiewi - Trejqa tal-Providenza - Church of Our Lady of Divine Providence 05 ies.jpg|thumb|[[Portico]] of the Church of Our Lady of Divine Providence in [[Siġġiewi]], which was designed by Cachia in 1815]] '''Michele Cachia''' ({{lang-mt|Mikiel Cachia}}, 30 September 1760 – 24 January 1839) was a [[Maltese people|Maltese]] architect and military engineer. He is also known for his role during the [[Siege of Malta (1798–1800)|Maltese uprising]] of 1798–1800. ==Life== Michele Cachia was born on 30 September 1760 in the town of [[Żejtun]]. He was the cousin of [[Antonio Cachia]], another architect and engineer.{{cite journal|last1=Spiteri|first1=Stephen C.|authorlink1=Stephen C. Spiteri|title=Fort Tigné 1792|journal=Arx – International Journal of Military Architecture and Fortification|date=2011|issue=1|page=65|url=https://issuu.com/arkitettura/docs/forttigne?e=1720231/2966495}} In April 1784, he applied for the post of ''perito agrimensore''. Like his father and grandfather, Cachia also worked in the construction of the [[Church of St Catherine, Żejtun|Żejtun Parish Church]]. He was also an [[adjutant]] within the Żejtun militia while [[History of Malta under the Order of Saint John|Malta was ruled by the Order of St. John]]. Cachia took part in the [[Siege of Malta (1798–1800)|Maltese uprising]] of 1798–1800 against the [[French occupation of Malta]]. He designed a number of [[Fortifications of Malta#French occupation (1798–1800)|batteries]] for the insurgents, including the [[Corradino Batteries]], [[Tal-Borg Battery]] and the [[Żejtun Batteries]]. In 1799, he also designed a [[gunpowder magazine]] at [[San Rocco Battery]].{{cite journal|last1=Spiteri|first1=Stephen C.|title=Maltese ‘siege’ batteries of the blockade 1798–1800|journal=Arx – Online Journal of Military Architecture and Fortification|date=May 2008|issue=6|pages=16, 34|url=http://www.militaryarchitecture.com/images/stories/Arx/arx6-2008.pdf|accessdate=5 September 2015}} Between 1801 and 1821, Cachia lived in [[Floriana]], a suburb of the capital [[Valletta]]. In 1802, he went to England as part of a delegation of Maltese people. Cachia was responsible for the construction of the hospital in [[Victoria, Gozo|Rabat, Gozo]]. His most famous work is the [[portico]] of the Church of Our Lady of Divine Providence in [[Siġġiewi]], which he designed after the church was damaged by a lightning strike in 1815{{cite book|last1=Schiavone|first1=Michael J.|title=Dictionary of Maltese Biographies Vol. 1 A-F|date=2009|publisher=Pubblikazzjonijiet Indipendenza|location=[[Pietà, Malta|Pietà]]|isbn=9789993291329|page=383}} The church had been built in the 18th century to designs of [[Andrea Belli]]. Cachia had a collection of notebooks containing personal notes about property in [[Valletta]]. 217 notebooks have survived, and they contain a lot of information about the city in the late 18th and early 19th centuries.{{cite web|last1=Zammit|first1=Andrè|title=Valletta and Michele Cachia (1760 –1839) – A factual appraisal through his notebooks|url=http://mhs.eu.pn/60/60_26.html|website=mhs.eu.pn|accessdate=4 September 2015}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cachia, Michele}} [[Category:1760 births]] [[Category:1839 deaths]] [[Category:Maltese military engineers]] [[Category:Maltese military personnel]] [[Category:Maltese rebels]] [[Category:People from Żejtun]] [[Category:18th-century Maltese architects]] [[Category:19th-century Maltese architects]] {{Malta-stub}}

{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Ministry of Revenues and Duties
Міністерство доходів і зборів
(2012-2014, dissolved) |nativename = |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo = MDZU logo.jpeg |logo_width =220px |logo_caption = |seal = Lesser Coat of Arms of Ukraine.svg |seal_width = 100px |seal_caption = Coat of arms of Ukraine |formed = 24 December 2012 |date1 = |date1_name = |date2 = |date2_name = |preceding1 = State Tax Service and the State Customs Service |dissolved = 27 May 2014 |superseding = |jurisdiction = {{UKR}} |headquarters = [[Kiev]] |latd = |latm = |lats = |latNS = |longd = |longm = |longs = |longEW = |employees = |budget = |minister1_name = |minister1_pfo = |minister2_name = |minister2_pfo = |chief1_name = |chief1_position = |parent_agency = [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine|Cabinet of Ministers]] |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |child3_agency = |website = |footnotes = }} {{Politics of Ukraine}} The '''Ministry of Revenues and Duties''' ({{lang-uk|Міністерство доходів і зборів України}}) was a government ministry of [[Ukraine]]. The ministry was created on 24 December 2012 by a Decree of [[Ukrainian President]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]] and it merged the country's State Tax Service and the State Customs Service.{{Cite web|url=http://bp.ubr.ua/profile/klimenko-aleksandr-viktorovich|title=UBR – АЛЕКСАНДР ВИКТОРОВИЧ КЛИМЕНКО – биография}}[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/klymenko-becomes-head-of-new-revenues-and-duties-ministry-318100.html], [[Kyiv Post]] ( Dec. 24, 2012) Its first and only minister was [[Oleksandr Viktorovych Klymenko|Oleksandr Klymenko]].[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/klymenko-becomes-head-of-new-revenues-and-duties-ministry-318100.html], [[Kyiv Post]] ( Dec. 24, 2012) On 1 March 2014 the ministry was liquidated.[http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/cardnpd?docid=247085827 About liquidation of the Ministry of Revenues and Duties]. Government portal. March 1, 2014 Its agencies were transferred to the [[Ministry of Finance (Ukraine)|Ministry of Finance]]. On May 27, 2014 it was announced that the ministry will be reorganized into the [[State Fiscal Service (Ukraine)|State Fiscal Service]] and will be subordinated to the Ministry of Finances.[https://web.archive.org/web/20150202041118/http://espreso.tv/news/2014/05/27/zamist_mindokhodiv_teper_bude_derzhavna_fiskalna_sluzhba___yacenyuk Yatsenyuk left the Arbuov's child, but renamed it into the State Fiscal Service]. Espreso.tv. 27 May 2014 ==Corruption case== The building of this ministry contained a large [[jacuzzi]]; [[Angel|angelic]] [[fresco]] on the ceiling; a deluxe [[sauna]] and a "salt room" (with the floor and ceiling covered in salt); allegedly [[bare-knuckle boxing]] matches were held in a specially designed room for it in the building.http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2618083/Ukraines-tax-office-massage-tables-tanning-booth-boxing-gym.html#ixzz3OdGUk3f5 Boxing gym, tanning booth, hi-tech jacuzzi and a salt room. No, it’s not an expensive health spa… just some of the facilities at Ukraine’s corrupt former tax office], [[DailyMail]] (1 May 2014) Since 31 May 2014 Klymenko is wanted by the [[General Prosecutor of Ukraine]] for the creation of [[tax evasion]] procedures to significantly reducing the customs value of certain companies. An alleged example of this is the setting up of non-existing firms to whittle tax obligations.[http://www.foxnews.com/world/2014/06/10/ap-impact-wide-scale-ukrainian-scam-intercepted-billions-in-taxes-using-fake/ AP IMPACT: Wide scale Ukrainian scam intercepted billions in taxes using fake companies], [[Fox News]] (June 10, 2014) This and other alleged crimes are to have costed the state budget of Ukraine 6 billion [[Ukrainian hryvnia]].{{ru icon}}'''/(website has automatic [[Google Translate]] option)''' [http://file.liga.net/person/3778-aleksandr-klimenko.html Short bio], LIGA Klymenko has denied all allegations against him and has called them "groundless".[http://www.foxnews.com/world/2014/06/10/ap-impact-wide-scale-ukrainian-scam-intercepted-billions-in-taxes-using-fake/ AP IMPACT: Wide scale Ukrainian scam intercepted billions in taxes using fake companies], [[Fox News]] (June 10, 2014) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Portal|Ukraine|Transport}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/*/http://mintrans.gov.ua Ministry of Transportation and Communication] (Archive) {{uk icon}} [[Category:2012 establishments in Ukraine]] [[Category:2014 disestablishments in Ukraine]] [[Category:Former government ministries of Ukraine|Revenues and Duties]] [[Category:Ministries established in 2012]] [[Category:Ministries disestablished in 2014]] [[Category:Public works ministries|Ukraine]] [[Category:Revenue services|Ukraine]] [[Category:Government finances in Ukraine]] {{Ukraine-stub}}
